questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion for irritable bowel syndrome?

options.b: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast

questions.explanation: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48-hour fast is not a diagnostic criteria for IBS.

questions.question: Question 2: The most common pattern seen in irritable bowel syndrome patients is

options.d: Constipation alternating with episodes of diarrhoea

questions.explanation:
The most common pattern in IBS patients is constipation alternating with episodes of diarrhoea. Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as: • IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant • IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhoea predominant • IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed 378 
Sold by @itachibot The majority of patients change subtypes over the course of illness. Note: Abdominal pain is a pre-requisite for the diagnosis of IBS. This means that for the diagnosis 
of IBS, recurrent abdominal pain must be present.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presents with a 3-month history of crampy abdominal pain associated with 
diarrhea. Which of the following features, if present, will support a diagnosis of irritable 
bowel syndrome?

options.c: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast
options.d: Onset of symptoms during a period of stress

questions.explanation:
The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a 
diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Features in favour of IBS: • Abdominal pain that improves/worsens with defecation • Association with stress or emotional symptoms • Small volume of stools Features not in favour of IBS: • Onset of symptoms in old age • Presence of fever and weight loss • Persistent diarrhoea after a 48h fast • Nocturnal diarrhoea • Steatorrhoea

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not implicated in the pathogenesis of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Decreased colonic motor potentials are not implicated in the pathogenesis of irritable bowel 
syndrome (IBS). On the contrary, increased colonic motor potentials are seen. The pathogenesis of IBS is poorly understood. However, the following have been implicated in its 
pathogenesis: • Increased colonic motor potentials lead to increased high-amplitude propagating contractions 
(HAPCs) which causes diarrhea. • Visceral hypersensitivity leads to exaggerated sensory responses to visceral stimulation by food. 
This explains the postprandial symptoms in IBS. • CNS dysregulation - dysfunctional activation of the mid-cingulate cortex and prefrontal lobes 
leads to increased perception of visceral pain. • Abnormal serotonin pathways - serotonin-containing enterochromaffin cells are increased in IBS 
patients. • Altered gut flora 379 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 35-year-old housewife has been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome - diarrhea 
predominant. Which neurotransmitter is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Serotonin is associated with irritable bowel syndrome diarrhoea type (IBS-D). Abnormal serotonin pathways is one of the causes for symptoms in IBS. The serotonin containing 
enterochromaffin cells are increased in a subset of IBS-D patients. This provides a rationale for 
the use of serotonin antagonists in the treatment of this condition.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following parts of the brain are associated with irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Mid cingulate cortex and prefrontal lobe are associated with IBS. Mid cingulate cortex: Modulation of this region is associated with changes in the subjective 
unpleasantness of pain. Prefrontal lobe: Dysfunction of this area leads to the increased perception of visceral pain.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a risk factor for post-infectious irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Male gender is not a risk factor for post-infectious IBS. Post-infectious IBS develops following a gastrointestinal infection with microbes such as 
Campylobacter, Salmonella and Shigella. Risk factors for developing post-infectious IBS: • Young age and female gender • Prolonged duration of illness • Toxicity of infecting bacterial strain • Smoking • Depression • Hypochondriasis

questions.question:
Question 8: In a suspected case of irritable bowel syndrome, which of the following investigations is not 
recommended?

options.c: Stool examination for ova and parasites

questions.explanation:
A stool fat test is not recommended in a suspected case of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents 
with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most 
patients to rule out other conditions: • Complete blood count • Sigmoidoscopic examination • Stool examination for ova and parasites 380 
Sold by @itachibot • 3-week lactose-free diet In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following is a marker of inflammatory bowel disease, which helps to rule out 
irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Fecal lactoferrin is the marker of IBD that is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome. Fecal 
lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation. Fecal calprotectin is another marker of IBD and it is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome and 
bacterial overgrowth. It correlates well with histologic inflammation, predicts relapses, and 
detects pouchitis. Option A: Fecal fat is normally digested by pancreatic lipase and absorbed from the jejunum. In 
disorders of exocrine pancreatic function, fat absorption decreases, resulting in steatorrhea and 
increased fecal fat. Options C & D: Fecal trypsin, chymotrypsin are pancreatic enzymes, therefore a decrease in 
fecal levels below normal suggests a disorder of the exocrine pancreas.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following statements is false regarding the FODMAPs diet recommended for a 
patient with irritable bowel syndrome?

options.b: Diet low in FODMAPs reduces symptoms in IBS patients
options.c: Sorbitol is an example of FODMAP
options.d: FODMAPs are highly absorbed by the small intestine

questions.explanation:
FODMAPs are poorly absorbed in the small intestine. FODMAPs stands for Fermentable Oligosaccharides, Disaccharides, Monosaccharides, And 
Polyols. Foodstuff containing lactose, fructose, and sorbitol are some examples of FODMAPs. Since FODMAPs are poorly absorbed, they are fermented by gut bacteria in the colon to produce 
gas and osmotically active carbohydrates. So, a diet low in FODMAPs is recommended to reduce 
symptoms in IBS patients.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 35-year-old woman with constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome presents with 
worsening abdominal pain and bloating. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed for 
her condition?
questions.explanation:
Lubiprostone is used in the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS. Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator that promotes the secretion of water and chloride 
into the bowel and improves bowel movements. Loperamide, alosetron, and eluxadoline (opioid mu receptor agonist) are used in the treatment of 
diarrhea-predominant IBS.

questions.question:
Question 12: 376 
Sold by @itachibot You have prescribed paroxetine to a patient with irritable bowel syndrome. This medication is 
most effective in reducing which of the following symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Paroxetine is most effective in treating constipation. It is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor 
(SSRI) that accelerates oro-caecal transit. 381 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Citalopram is an SSRI that is effective in the management of pain in IBS. It blunts 
perception of rectal distension and reduces the magnitude of gastrocolic reflex.

questions.question:
Question 13: Drug 'X', a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist, is prescribed to treat a patient with 
diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Identify the drug 'X'.
questions.explanation:
Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS–D. Options B and C: Tegaserod and lubiprostone are used in the treatment of 
constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS–C). Option D: Ondansetron is used in the treatment of nausea and vomiting.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with irritable bowel disease was started on a drug. A few days after administration 
of the drug, the patient complained of acute ’I distress suggestive of ischemic colitis. What 
was the drug taken by the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ischaemic colitis is a side-effect of alosetron. Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is used to reduce diarrhoea in irritable bowel 
syndrome. Option A: Lubiprostone is associated with nausea and diarrhea. Option B: Linaclotide is associated with diarrhea. Option D: Tegaserod is associated with cardiac toxicity.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 28-year-old female patient comes to you for advice. She is a known case of irritable bowel 
syndrome. She asks you when is the best time to take antispasmodics for her postprandial 
abdominal pain. What would you suggest?
questions.explanation:
The best time to take antispasmodics for postprandial pain is 30 min before meals. Antispasmodics such as dicyclomine inhibit the gastrocolic reflex and thus reduce pain due to 
intestinal spasms. It is best taken 30 min before meals so that the effective blood levels are 
achieved shortly before the anticipated onset of pain. 382 
Sold by @itachibot Inflammatory Bowel Disease - Clinical Features and Diagnosis
